awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Timing and Spatial Expression of the Bipolar Seesaw in Antarctica from Synchronized Ice Cores
awd_abstract_narration:
Buizert/1643394

This award supports a project to use ice cores to study teleconnections between the northern hemisphere, tropics, and Antarctica during very abrupt climate events that occurred during the last ice age (from 70,000 to 11,000 years ago). The observations can be used to test scientific theories about the role of the westerly winds on atmospheric carbon dioxide. In a warming world, snow fall in Antarctica is expected to increase, which can reduce the Antarctic contribution to sea level rise, all else being equal. The study will investigate how snow fall changed in the past in response to changes in temperature and atmospheric circulation, which can help improve projections of future sea level rise.  Antarctica is important for the future evolution of our planet in several ways; it has the largest inventory of land-based ice, equivalent to about 58 m of global sea level and currently contributes about 0.3 mm per year to global sea level rise, which is expected to increase in the future due to global warming. The oceans surrounding Antarctica help regulate the uptake of human-produced carbon dioxide. Shifts in the position and strength of the southern hemisphere westerly winds could change the amount of carbon dioxide that is absorbed by the ocean, which will influence the rate of global warming. The climate and winds near and over Antarctica are linked to the rest of our planet via so-called climatic teleconnections. This means that climate changes in remote places can influence the climate of Antarctica. Understanding how these climatic teleconnections work in both the ocean and atmosphere is an important goal of climate research.  The funds will further contribute towards training of a postdoctoral researcher and an early-career researcher; outreach to public schools; and the communication of research findings to the general public via the media, local events, and a series of Wikipedia articles. 

The project will help to fully characterize the timing and spatial pattern of millennial-scale Antarctic climate change during the deglaciation and Dansgaard-Oeschger (DO) cycles using multiple synchronized Antarctic ice cores. The phasing of Antarctic climate change relative to Greenland DO events can distinguish between fast atmospheric teleconnections on sub-decadal timescales, and slow oceanic ones on centennial time scales. Preliminary work suggests that the spatial pattern of Antarctic change can fingerprint specific changes to the atmospheric circulation; in particular, the proposed work will clarify past movements of the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds during the DO cycle, which have been hypothesized. The project will help resolve a discrepancy between two previous seminal studies on the precise timing of interhemispheric coupling between ice cores in both hemispheres. The study will further provide state-of-the-art, internally-consistent ice core chronologies for all US Antarctic ice cores, as well as stratigraphic ties that can be used to integrate them into a next-generation Antarctic-wide ice core chronological framework. Combined with ice-flow modeling, these chronologies will be used for a continent-wide study of the relationship between ice sheet accumulation and temperature during the last deglaciation.

por.por_cntn:
Ice cores from the polar regions provide high-resolution records of past climate and greenhouse gases going back as far as 800,000 years. To interpret these climate records, scientists need to know very precisely how old the ice is at each depth layer in the core. Volcanic eruptions are an important tool in understanding the age of various ice cores. Volcanic eruptions inject large amounts of sulfur-rich aerosols into the atmosphere that are preserved in ice cores as thin sulfate layers. These sulfur layers can be used to synchronize the age scales of ice cores drilled in different sectors of Antarctica, or even to synchronize ice cores drilled in Antarctica with those drilled in Greenland.

This project performed volcanic matching of sulfate layers in the US-drilled West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide ice core with sulfate layers in five other Antarctic ice cores. The project also contributed to an international effort to match up volcanic layers in ice cores from Antarctica and Greenland. The WAIS Divide ice core has a more accurate age scale than other Antarctic ice cores, and the volcanic matching makes it possible to synchronize the other ice cores to the WAIS Divide age scale. In this way the project contributed to improving the age scale of several ice cores, which will aid future research on these cores.

The volcanic framework made it possible to learn more about the relationship and relative phasing of climate changes seen in Greenland (representing the northern hemisphere) and Antarctica (representing the southern hemisphere). Climate change in one part of the Earth can cause changes of the climate elsewhere, a process called a climatic teleconnection. Such teleconnections happen on different timescales: changes to the atmospheric wind patterns manifest themselves quickly within weeks to a year, whereas changes to oceanic currents can take hundreds of years to unfold.

During the last ice age, the climate of the North Atlantic experienced several extremely abrupt climate change events, the co-called Dansgaard-Oeschger events, during which Greenland ice cores show as much as 10oC of abrupt warming within a few decades. These abrupt climate change events are likely caused by changes to the Atlantic Ocean circulation. The project showed that Antarctic climate is impacted by these Dansgaard-Oeschger events on two distinct timescales. First, there is an immediate impact in Antarctica that has no time-delay behind the abrupt Greenland events. This first mode of climate change shows up as cooling in one Antarctic ice core location, and as warming in several other locations. Based on the timing of this mode, it suggests an atmospheric teleconnection. Second, there is a 150-year-delayed cooling response all over Antarctica via an oceanic teleconnection called the ?thermal bipolar seesaw?, that had been described in previous work.

Results from the project suggest that this first atmospheric teleconnection reflects a southward shift of the mean position of the southern hemisphere westerly winds around Antarctica. These winds play a key role in regulating global ocean circulation, and possibly also in controlling the storage of carbon in the deep ocean. Understanding the dynamics of these winds better is a key goal of (paleo) climate research, in particular as theory suggest they may also shift southward in the future in response to currently ongoing climate warming.

The volcanic ice core synchronization also made it possible for the project to estimate how much Antarctica cooled during the last Ice Age, around 20,000 years ago, using two different techniques. Previous studies based on water isotope ratios suggested that Antarctic surface temperatures were around 9oC colder than during the preindustrial period. The new estimates suggest instead that surface temperatures in central East Antarctica were only 4 to 5oC colder, around half of the previous estimates. These new estimates will allow for testing climate models under conditions very different from today, and also solve a long-standing problem in ice core research regarding the thickness of the Antarctic firn layer (the 60 to 120 m thick snow pack) during the last Ice Age.

The project provided opportunities for professional development for the principle investigator, who is an untenured faculty member at Oregon State University. As part of this project, the principle investigator coordinated and participated in annual outreach to middle schools in the region, reaching around 15-20 classrooms annually for a day of polar science with presentations and hands-on activities; during the COVID-19 pandemic this outreach happened virtually. Outcomes of the research were disseminated to scientific audiences via peer reviewed publications, seminars, and conference presentations and to the broader public via press releases and media articles on two occasions.
